hints.content: Start by understanding what it means for an array to be consecutive. An array is consecutive if each element is exactly one more than the previous element when sorted. For example, [1, 2, 3] is consecutive, but [1, 3, 2] is not.
Consider how you can identify the smallest and largest elements in the array. This will help you determine the expected range of numbers if the array were to be consecutive.
Think about how you can check if all numbers in the range from the minimum to the maximum are present in the array. You might want to use a set for this purpose.
Remember to account for duplicates in the array. If there are any duplicates, the array cannot be consecutive. How can you check for duplicates efficiently?
Before diving into the main logic, consider edge cases such as an empty array or an array with only one element. What should your function return in those cases?

Once you have identified the minimum and maximum values and checked for duplicates, you can calculate the expected length of a consecutive array. This length should equal the maximum minus the minimum plus one.
Now that you have the expected length, compare it with the actual number of unique elements in your array. If they don't match, the array is not consecutive.
To implement your solution, you might want to sort the array first. However, sorting is not strictly necessary if you can use a set to check for duplicates and the range of numbers.
Consider the time complexity of your solution. Using a set can give you average O(1) time complexity for lookups, which can be beneficial when checking for the presence of numbers.
Finally, make sure to return a boolean value indicating whether the array is consecutive or not. This will be your final output after all checks.

questionNotes: The array can contain negative numbers.
Elements in the array must be unique for it to be consecutive.
Return true if the array is consecutive, otherwise return false.
An empty array or an array with one element should be considered consecutive.
